docs.lead_paragraph: Belladonna was once used by women as a cosmetic trick to dilate their pupils. As a drug called atropine, opthalmologists use it to dilate the pupil during eye examinations. It blocks the action of acetylcholine, a nerve-fiber chemical transmitter, inhibiting sweating and interfering with the body's temperature regulation. Use of atropine by eye doctors in the hot, dry climate of Baghdad led to fatal heat stroke. Fortunately, atropine is well-known as a weather-sensitive drug. Its spectacular side effects not only drew attention to itself but also implied that there were entire drug families whose effects in the body were altered by external temperature-humidity conditions or by sunlight.

docs.lead_paragraph: Governor Carey signed a bill today that would make it illegal for a physician to prescribe amphetamines for the sole purpose of helping a patient lose weight. The bill prohibits the use of such drugs for the ''exclusive treatment'' of ''obsesity, weight loss or weight control.'' A doctor who so prescribed an amphetamine would not be subject to prosecution, but Mr. Carey said the legislation would permit the state's Health Department to bring disciplinary procedings against physicians ''who persist in prescribing amphetamines for weight control.''

byline.original: By E. J. DIONNE Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, had a major seizure today, a new side effect of the head injuries he suffered in the assassination attempt on President Reagan March 30. The grand mal seizure struck Mr. Brady shortly after he had breakfast in his room at George Washington University Hospital, said Larry Speakes, the deputy press secretary. Doctors immediately began treatment with intravenous medications and anesthesia, Mr. Speakes said. Mr. Brady's vital signs were reported to be normal, and he was sleeping. His brain waves were being monitored by an electroencephalograph.
